Lazy Anansi 
 Ghanaian folktale
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Once upon a time, there was a spider
 caled Anansi. 
 He was to lazy to cok his own fod.
 
 Instead, he used to visit his friends and
 eat the delicious fod they had coked.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day, he was walking past Rabit’s 
 house when he smeled something 
 
 coking. 
 “Grens!” he said excitedly. 
 “They’re not quite ready yet,” said Rabit. 
 
 “You can help me with the washing up in 
 the mean time.” 
 
 “Sory, I have things to do. I’l come back 
 later,” said Anansi. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “How wil I cal you when they’re ready?”
 
 asked Rabit. 
 Anansi thought for a minute. 
 “I'l spin a web,” he said, “and tie one end
 
 around my leg and one end to your pot.
 When the grens are ready, pul on the
 web string and I’l come right away.”
 
 
 So Anansi tied the web to the pot, and
 
 walked on. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 A short while later he saw Monkey and 
 his wife, coking some beans in a large 
 
 pot. 
 “Come and join us!” they said. “The 
 beans are nearly ready.” 
 
 “Sory, I have things to do,” said Anansi 
 before they could ask him to help. 
 “But let me tie one end of this web 
 
 around my leg and one end to your pot. 
 When the beans are ready, pul on the 
 
 web string, and I’l come.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 He walked on until he smeled swet
 potatoes. 
 
 “Anansi,” caled his friend Warthog. “My
 pot is ful of swet potatoes and honey!
 Come and share my fod with me. Here’s
 
 a fork for you to help me stir.”
 
 “I’l come back later,” said Anansi quickly.
 
 “But let me tie one end of this web
 around my leg and one end to your pot.
 
 When the swet potatoes are ready, pul
 on the web string, and I’l come.”
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 By the time Anansi arived at the river, 
 
 each of his eight legs was tied to a 
 diferent pot of delicious fod. 
 Just then, Anansi felt a tug on one of his 
 
 legs. 
 “Rabit’s fod is ready!” he said, licking 
 
 his lips. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 He felt a second tug. 
 And a third. 
 And a fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh, eighth.
 
 Everyone was puling on the web strings
 at the same time! 
 “Stop! Stop!” he cried in pain, as his legs
 
 were stretched thiner and thiner.
 But no one could hear him. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Finaly, the web strings could hold no 
 longer. They snaped one by one. 
 Anansi roled into the river to sothe his 
 
 painful legs. But his legs would not 
 return to their normal shape. 
 And he was to embarased to go to 
 
 any of his friends and share their fod 
 that day. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8
